entry.title: Combined summary - Unlimited Max Blocksize (reprise)
entry.summary: Peter R and Daniele recently had an email conversation regarding the optimality of a greedy algorithm mentioned in a paper. They both agreed that the algorithm is asymptotically optimal in a certain case, but no further information or context was provided.It is unclear what specific paper they were discussing or what the algorithm was designed for. However, it can be inferred that Peter and Daniele have expertise in the field of algorithms and are familiar with the concept of asymptotic optimality.It is also possible that the discussion may have been related to blockchain technology, as the phrase "mine centralization" is mentioned in passing. It is worth noting that in the context of blockchain, eliminating mine centralization is considered important for improving the security and decentralization of the network.The writer questions the community's acceptance of complex miner voting protocols as a hard fork option, while suggesting a controlled raising of the max blocksize in the interim to ease into the fee market dynamic described as the best option.The main critique to uncapped max blocksizes is the advantage that large miners have over smaller ones, but the writer argues that these advantages do not stem from propagating large blocks but rather from block subsidies allowing miners to mine unnecessary large blocks regardless of the fees contained therein.In this context, large blocksizes, as proposed by BIP100-101, hope to stimulate the increase of TX fees by augmenting the network's capacity. Comparable to block fees, the sooner mine centralization can be eliminated.
